hints.Matter: Anything that has mass and occupies space.
hints.Atoms: The smallest units of an element that maintain the properties of that element.
hints.Elements: Pure substances consisting of only one type of atom.
hints.Compounds: Substances formed by the combination of two or more elements in a fixed ratio.
hints.Molecules: Groups of two or more atoms bonded together.
hints.Chemical reactions: Processes that change one set of chemicals into another set of chemicals.
hints.Periodic table: A chart of elements arranged by atomic number and grouped by similar properties.
hints.Chemical bonds: Forces that hold atoms together in molecules or compounds.
hints.States of matter (solid, liquid, gas): The physical forms in which matter exists.
hints.Physical and chemical properties: Characteristics of substances that can be observed or measured without changing their chemical identity.
hints.Mixtures and solutions: Mixtures are combinations of two or more substances that are not chemically bonded, while solutions are homogeneous mixtures of solutes and solvents.
hints.Acids and bases: Acids are substances that release hydrogen ions (H+) when dissolved in water, while bases release hydroxide ions (OH-).
hints.pH scale: A measure of acidity or alkalinity of a solution, ranging from 0 (most acidic) to 14 (most basic).
hints.Conservation of mass: The principle that the total mass of substances in a closed system remains constant during a chemical reaction.
hints.Chemical formulas: Notations that represent the composition of a compound using element symbols and numbers to show the ratio of atoms.
hints.Chemical equations: Representations of chemical reactions using symbols and formulas to show the reactants and products.
hints.Atomic structure: The arrangement of subatomic particles (protons, neutrons, and electrons) within an atom.
hints.Protons, neutrons, and electrons: Subatomic particles that make up atoms; protons carry a positive charge, neutrons have no charge, and electrons carry a negative charge.
hints.Chemical energy: The potential energy stored in chemical bonds.
hints.Law of conservation of energy: The principle that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted from one form to another.
